item.title: Ticket #1270 (Add "echo" option to wp_list_pages ( as well as _page_level_out() )) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description:
Well, the use case for me was that I wanted to use wp_list_pages() in a 'the_content' filter. Wrote a plugin that replaces <!--subpages--> with the list of pages under that current page (had a lot of requests for this).

So I need to be able to do a str_replace() to put in wp_list_pages() for <!--subpages-->

Yes, I could make a copy of the function, rename it, and modify it... but that seems silly when all I need is wp_list_pages() with a return instead of an echo.

item.title: Ticket #1268 (new excerpt function suggestion) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy

item.title: Ticket #1268 (new excerpt function suggestion) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
a few dozen test cases later, it is:

$excerpt = preg_replace( "/\W*(\w+(\W+\w+){".($excerpt_length-1)."}((?!(\.|\n|\r)).)*(\.|\n|\r))(\w|\W)+/", "$1 (...)", $excerpt );

rather than /(\w+(\W+\w+){".($excerpt_length-1)."}[\.]*\.)[$]+/

item.title: Ticket #1197 (Feed RRS add several enclosures when only one is correct) closed
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description:
20:

Fixed the bug where multiple enclosures would be created for the same item. Enclosures for each item is not contradicted by the spec and supported by the new generation of podcasting software, file a bug with the podcasting software maker if it isn't yet.

item.dc:creator: matt

item.title: Ticket #1269 (Excerpt ignoring <!--noteaser-->) updated
item.dc:creator: henrpyijames
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1269 (Excerpt ignoring <!--noteaser-->) created
item.dc:creator: henrpyijames
item.description:
The current excerpt generation algorithm does not respect <!--noteaser--> as it should. Often, a teaser constitutes a good summary of the post already, especially if <!--noteaser--> is specified, which basically meens the teaser and the rest should not been seen together, most propably because there is redundancy in the content.

Therefor, an excerpt shall not go beyound <!--more--><!--noteaser-->, but simply copy the teaser (or shorten it if too long) instead. Also, we can go one step further and argue a teaser is always good enough as an excerpt, and cut the excerpt at <!--more--> regardless of if <!--noteaser--> is following or not.

item.title: Ticket #1248 (Editing posts produces linebreak madness) updated

item.description: ​http://trac.wordpress.org/changeset/2559

item.title: Ticket #1268 (new excerpt function suggestion) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
I added the file to the alpha version of my plugin. I left the test code at the end of it, should you want to play with it.

The backlink_excerpt method is extremely forgiving to html errors and will eat all but the worst coded html pages.

I think there is room for a few more enhancements. In particular, if you have:

  • upper text
  • <a ...>blah blah</a>
  • lower text

The excerpt will be 'blah blah', whereas it would make more sense to have the upper and lower text. But presumably, it remains good enough for now.

item.title: Ticket #1248 (Editing posts produces linebreak madness) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description:
I say we kill it, and wait for a 1.6 or at least a 1.5.2 release to really flesh this out better, maybe even exploring an AJAX solution. No use delaying the 1.5.1 release because of bugs introduced by a brand new experimental feature.

Please don't flame me. :-)

item.title: Ticket #1268 (new excerpt function suggestion) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description: the above works a bit like wp_trim_excerpt, but returns full sentences.

item.title: Ticket #1268 (new excerpt function suggestion) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1268 (new excerpt function suggestion) created
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
/*

  • sem_fancy_excerpt()
  • -------------------
  • Creates a fancy default excerpt

/

function sem_fancy_excerpt( $excerpt ) { global $post;

$excerpt_length = 30;

if ( $excerpt == ) {

$excerpt = $post->post_content; $excerpt = apply_filters( 'the_content', $excerpt ); $excerpt = strip_tags( $excerpt ); $excerpt = preg_replace( "/(\w+(\W+\w+){".($excerpt_length-1)."}[\.]*\.)[$]+/", "$1 (...)", $excerpt );

} return $excerpt; } end sem_fancy_excerpt()

remove_filter('get_the_excerpt', 'wp_trim_excerpt'); add_filter('get_the_excerpt', 'sem_fancy_excerpt');

item.title: Ticket #1267 (Edit mode changes < to < (also >)) updated
item.dc:creator: htodd
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1267 (Edit mode changes < to < (also >)) created
item.dc:creator: htodd
item.description:
Sorry, I'm spelling this out in case mosquito does odd conversions into html.

In a post that includes the less-than sign (used in tags) as text using the ampersand lt semicolon, editing changes that directly to the less-than symbol. (The greater-than operates in a similar fashion.) Saving that post causes problems because the angle brackets are now handled as a tag.

I've attached the fix as bug1263_pluggable-functions2.php. It required obtaining the currentuser info instead of just a variable change. I also inserted it at a point where it saves the query to the user table if the commenter is an admin/post_author.

i get the same thing as you do, in fact. i tried installing a fresh install, and i indeed get no problem with it.

despite this, my options are so that the main blog's feed and the dev blog's feed should display the 5 recent posts rather than the last one only.

i disabled all the plugins from my dev site, and the problem remains. it looks as if something somewhere stored that it should only display one post.

i'm investigating...

item.title: Ticket #1263 (Don't notify admins and post_authors of their own comments) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
Then I'm confused:

$comment = $wpdb->get_row("SELECT * FROM $wpdb->comments WHERE comment_ID='$comment_id' LIMIT 1"); $post = $wpdb->get_row("SELECT * FROM $wpdb->posts WHERE ID='$comment->comment_post_ID' LIMIT 1"); $user = $wpdb->get_row("SELECT * FROM $wpdb->users WHERE ID='$post->post_author' LIMIT 1");

Isn't $user->ID always equal to $post->post_author by definition of the SQL query? User seems to refer to the author of the post, not the currently logged in user (which is defined in $comment).

item.title: Ticket #1265 (Add simple check for duplicate comments) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1265 (Add simple check for duplicate comments) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1265 (Add simple check for duplicate comments) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: A check for duplicate comments can help prevent some types of spam, mad-clicking commenters, and those trying to repost their comment. Applies to trackbacks/pingbacks as well (though they have their own dupe check, I believe).

item.title: Ticket #1263 (Don't notify admins and post_authors of their own comments) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
No, we'd want what the patch has:

if ( $post->post_author == $user->ID
$user->user_level >= 9 ) return false;

and not

if ( $comment->user_id == $user->ID
$user->user_level >= 9 ) return false;

$user->ID is the ID of the logged-in person who posted the comment, which is the same as $comment->user_id, so it'd always be equal. What the comparison is doing is seeing if the author of the post is the person currently logged-in/commenting.

---

Also, I opted not to pursue an e-mail based solution because the admin's e-mail may well be known. Spammers could scrape the e-mail from the site (or try to) and make comments using the admin's e-mail, which if used as the non-nontification trigger might mean the admin won't realize the site has been spammed without actually checking the site or the admin comment listings (assuming the spam got through spam filters).

--- Personally, I think self-notification e-mails should be disabled by default. The notification functions can be overridden by plugins which could active the self-notifications for those who want it. Or the behavior could be controlled by an option, i.e.

if ( get_settings('disable_self_notification') && ($post->post_author == $user->ID
$user->user_level >= 9) ) return false;

item.title: Ticket #1263 (Don't notify admins and post_authors of their own comments) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
Sending a "notification" email also provides a backup. I find it handy (though I backup the database for real and have never had to use it). It's not a big deal to me either way.

The bug report does beg the question, however: Why not set up an email filter to delete (or whatever) any self comments? The patch takes away options while the filter just sucks up some processor ticks and bandwidth.

Since the function can be replaced by a plugin, why not just go that route instead? Or patch in a hook.

At any rate, shouldn't the patch read: + Don't notify admin or post_author about their own comment

+ if ( $comment->user_id == $user->ID
$user->user_level >= 9 ) return false;

item.title: Ticket #1261 (Remove svn:executable from streams.php and gettext.php) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
This can be fixed with

svn pd svn:executable wp-includes/streams.php svn pd svn:executable wp-includes/gettext.php svn ci

item.title: Ticket #1260 (r2552 switched pluggable-functions.php to DOS encoding) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Status, Resolution changed

This bug is not fixed. 2552 changed the linefeeds from unix style to dos style. Both is wrong, the file should have 'native' style (that means linefeeds will get converted from/to the client system's linefeed when checking out/commiting).

To fix this bug you have to:

  • Convert the linefeeds to what is 'native' on your platform
  • svn ps svn:eol-style native wp-includes/pluggable-functions.php
  • svn ci

item.title: Ticket #1264 (empty comments wont be rejected) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I often find this (empty) spam in my blog, probably they are checking if posting is allowed:

Author : (IP: 24.2.95.195 , c-24-2-95-195.hsd1.ut.comcast.net) E-mail : e URI : Comment:

The bot is using a whitespace as comment, so the comment will be accepted even though it should be rejected as empty

item.title: Ticket #1261 (Remove svn:executable from streams.php and gettext.php) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1261 (Remove svn:executable from streams.php and gettext.php) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
There's no reason for streams.php and gettext.php having the executable bit set, svn:executable prop should be removed:

% find . -type f -perm +u+x | xargs svn pl Properties on 'wp-includes/streams.php':

svn:executable svn:keywords svn:eol-style

Properties on 'wp-includes/gettext.php':

svn:executable svn:keywords svn:eol-style

item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: Almost done with cleanup.

item.title: Ticket #1238 (DB optimizations) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Oops. Right you are. I misread. We need to do this in get_category() too then.

item.title: Ticket #1238 (DB optimizations) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
er, cat_ID and category_id will be in the cache, with 4. cat_ID is fetched twice, which produces close to zero overhead in sql. but i guess do as you see fit. i'm OK with everything as long as the cache is around for me to use in my plugins. ;)

speaking of plugins, there's this line in wp-blog-header.php

update_category_cache();

by tracing the queries I found it occurs after the 'init' hook, during which a plugin may potentially set the category cache.

Replacing with:

if ( !isset($cache_categories) )

update_category_cache();

could save a few cycles too. :)

item.title: Ticket #1238 (DB optimizations) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Currently, we need both cat_ID and category_id in the cache or things will break. I'd rather get rid of "as category_id" and fix the few places that use category_id to use cat_ID instead. Actually, for 1.5.1 I would rather just revert.

edited on: 04-19-05 16:16

item.title: Ticket #1258 (Curly quotes mixups) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1258 (Curly quotes mixups) created
item.dc:creator: Denis de Bernardy
item.description:
I think there is a tiny problem in the wordpress text renduring:

when you use single quotes in the text, WP converts them to single fancy quotes. However, some quotes are transformed in the wrong direction.

e.g. if you type: 'products', 'services', you get â€˜productsâ€™, â€™servicesâ€™ rather than â€˜productsâ€™, â€˜servicesâ€™.

I think the problem comes from WP detecting something like /'s/ rather than /\w's/ â€™s

item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1257 (Pingbacks sent from wrong URI for posts first published in advanced ...) created
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description: Publishing a post from advanced editing mode will, if it is the first time the post has been published, send pingbacks from non-permalinked URIs: ​http://example.com/?p=204 rather than ​http://example.com/a-post/
